texts.content_text200: Marina is a 16-year-old girl involved in judicial proceedings following allegations of physical domestic abuse within her family. The court appoints you to represent her and safeguard her rights throughout the process.
texts.content_text201: Marina is shy, anxious, and initially distrustful of legal authorities. She finds formal meetings intimidating, so she begins communicating with you through WhatsApp, where she feels more comfortable expressing herself.
texts.content_text202:
Over time, she shares deeply sensitive personal information, including:
  • Details about the abuse she experienced at home
  • Her struggles with anxiety and depression
  • Conflicts at school and fear of stigma
  • Past traumatic experiences she has never disclosed before
texts.content_text203: You want to maintain Marina’s trust and ensure she feels heard. To keep track of her case, you store conversation notes and screenshots on your personal laptop so you can review them easily when preparing legal arguments. However, this device is not encrypted and is also used for other everyday purposes.
texts.content_text204: Later, you attend a legal conference where professionals discuss the challenges of representing children. Wanting to contribute meaningfully, you present Marina’s case as an example. You mention her first name and refer to specific factual circumstances to explain the complexity of working with vulnerable minors. You do not seek Marina’s consent, consult her guardian, or request authorisation from the court beforehand.
